sub_title: Professor of Structural and Functional Plasticity of the Nervous System at SILS-CNS, University of Amsterdam
summary:
Experienced Full Professor with a demonstrated history of working in neuroscience research. Skilled in Alzheimer's Disease, Depression, Cognition, (early) Stress, Hippocampus, Hypothalamus, Stem Cell Biology, Adult Neurogenesis, Brain Plasticity and Neurobiology. 
Professional with a MSc focused in Medical Biology / Neurobiology from the Free University, Amsterdam, a PhD from the University of Amsterdam and obtained at the Netherlands Institute for Neuroscience, postdoctoral experience at U Penn in the USA and at the LACDR in Leiden, group leader and chair, and master track coordinator at the Swammerdam Institute of the University of Amsterdam.

awards.title: Prof.Dr. Paul J Lucassen

- SILS Research Award for best publications and overall performance, 2014.

Professor of Structural and Functional Plasticity of the Nervous System at SILS-CNS, University of Amsterdam
Professor bij UMC Utrecht

profile_positions.description:
Domain of research: Structural plasticity, neurogenesis and stem cells in the brain.

My group studies structural and functional plasticity in the brain. We focus a.o., on stem cells in the brain that continue to form new neurons into adulthood, a process called 'adult neurogenesis' We try to understand how (early) stress exposure can modify neurogenesis and affect brain structure and function often for life, and parallel to that, the risk for brain disorders like depression and dementia.

We are further interested in the role of neurogenesis in human brain and in how the potential of stem cells and plasticity still present in the adult and aging brain can be utilized or recruited for improved functionality and brain repair. 

Main research questions;
- What defines plasticity in the adult brain ?
- Is this influenced by stress experienced during early, adolescent or adult life periods ?
- How can exposure to early life stress program brain structure and function “for life” ? 
- What are the underlying (molecular) mechanisms ?
- How do adult-generated neurons contribute to learning and memory and to hippocampus-related disorders ?
- How does early life stress influence the vulnerability to develop brain disorders ? Can this be modified by environmental stimulation or by pharmacological means ?
- To what extent is plasticity implicated in (human) brain (dys)function ? Is adult neurogenesis e.g. implicated in disorders affecting the hippocampus, like Alzheimer’s disease, epilepsy and depression ?

profile_positions.title: Board member

profile_positions.description:
As chairman of the Scientific Advisory Board (SAB), I have been responsible since 2009 for the evaluation procedure of research grants submitted to the former ISAO, now Alzheimer Nederland. Together with our German and French colleagues from AFI and LECMA, respectively, the Dutch SAB members review the on average 150 grants per year submitted to our organizations, on a wide range of topics related to Alzheimer's disease and dementia. 
The 24 members of the SABs of the 3 organizations represent the European SAB. They come together every year to discuss the projects, often with the applicants themselves, and eventually decide together about funding the best and most promising grants, that should be aimed at; improving our understanding of the fundamental mechanisms and origins of these devastating disorders, or aiding in their prevention and/or therapy.
profile_positions.title: Chairman of the Scientific Advisory board of Alzheimer Nederland
